turns.user_message: What are the main reasons doctors recommend childhood vaccinations, and how safe are they for kids?

## 1. Why do doctors recommend childhood vaccinations? | Reason | What it means in practice | How it is supported by evidence | |--------|--------------------------|---------------------------------| | **Prevent serious disease** | Vaccines protect children from infections that can cause hospitalization, permanent disability, or death (e.g., measles, polio, diphtheria, pertussis, Haemophilus influenzae type b). | • The World Health Organization (WHO) estimates that routine childhood immunization prevents ≈ 2–3 million deaths each year worldwide.
• U.S. CDC data show a >99 % decline in cases of diseases that were common before vaccines (e.g., measles → ≈ 600 cases in 2023 vs. > 3 million cases per year in the 1960s). | | **Herd (community) immunity** | When enough people are immune, the pathogen has difficulty finding susceptible hosts, protecting those who cannot be vaccinated (infants too young, immunocompromised, or those with certain medical contraindications). | • Mathematical models and real‑world outbreaks show that when coverage falls below the disease‑specific herd‑immunity threshold (e.g., ≈ 95 % for measles), outbreaks re‑emerge.
• The 2014‑2015 Disneyland measles outbreak in California occurred in a community with ≈ 85 % MMR coverage, illustrating loss of herd protection. | | **Economic and societal benefits** | Fewer sick days for families, lower health‑care costs, and reduced strain on schools and workplaces. | • A 2020 Institute of Medicine (now the National Academy of Medicine) analysis estimated that every $1 spent on U.S. childhood vaccines yields $3 – $10 in direct medical savings and $10 – $30 in broader societal savings. | | **Predictable, controlled exposure** | Natural infection can cause severe complications; vaccination gives immunity without the disease’s harmful effects. | • Polio: before the vaccine, ≈ 1 in 200 infections caused permanent paralysis; now < 1 case per year in the U.S.

The higher the R₀, the more “contagious” the pathogen. | | **Herd‑immunity threshold (HIT)** | The proportion of the population that must be immune (by vaccination or prior infection) for the **effective reproduction number (Rₑ)** to fall below 1, i.e., for each case to produce fewer than one new case on average.
